facts.text: Petitioner No. 1 was an Agricultural Demonstrator of the Government of Madras and was employed as an Assistant Marketing Officer in Central Provinces and Berar for the purchase and movement of blackgram and other grains on behalf of the Madras Government.
Petitioner No. 1, second petitioner and 44 others are under prosecution before Shri K. E. Pandey, a Special Magistrate of Nagpur, Madhya Pradesh, in Case No. I of 1949.

Prosecution charges: cheating, attempt to commit cheating, criminal breach of trust and criminal conspiracy, i.e., offences punishable under section 420 read with section 120-B or 109 of the Indian Penal Code, section 409 and section 409 read with section 120-B of the Indian Penal Code.
Allegation: by reason of the acts committed by the accused, the Government of Madras had to incur an expenditure of Rs. 3,57,147-10-0 in excess of the amount due.
Special Magistrate appointed by the Madhya Pradesh Government under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code.
Prosecution against first petitioner initiated by sanction given by the Government of Madras under section 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code.
Shri K. E. Pandey was first appointed as Special Magistrate, case transferred to him; later appointed as acting Sessions Judge and ceased to have the case; reverted back to original post.
Questions raised before High Court at previous stages by applications under article 226 and decided against petitioners; no appeals taken.

legal_issues.text: Section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, in so far as it authorises the Provincial Government to confer upon any person all or any of the powers conferred or conferrable by or under the Code on a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in respect of particular cases and thereby to constitute a Special Magistrate for the trial of an individual case, violates the guarantee under article 14 of the Constitution.

The sanction given under section 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code for the prosecution as against the first petitioner is invalid, inasmuch as the order of the Madras Government granting the sanction does not disclose that all the facts constituting the offences to be charged were placed before the sanctioning authority nor does the sanction state the time or place of the occurrence or the transactions involved in it, or the persons with whom the offences were committed.

Even if the sanction under section 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code is valid, it is for the very Government which accords the sanction to specify also the Court before which the trial is to be held under section 197(2) and in the absence of any such specification by the said Government, the power under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code of appointing a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case cannot be exercised by the Madhya Pradesh Government.

Without a fresh notification appointing Shri K. E. Pandey as Special Magistrate and transferring the case to him as such after his reversion from acting Sessions Judge, he cannot be said to be seized of this case as Special Magistrate.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 14 CrPC violates Art.14, relying on Anwar Ali Sarkar's case.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14 of Constitution; Anwar Ali Sarkar's case (1952 S.C.R. 284)

petitioner_arguments.text: Sanction under s.197(1) CrPC invalid as it does not disclose facts constituting offences, time, place, transactions or persons involved.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 197(1) CrPC; Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King (A.I.R. 1948 P.C. 82)

petitioner_arguments.text: Madras Govt which sanctioned must specify court under s.197(2); MP Govt cannot appoint Special Magistrate under s.14; non-exercise implies no special court; dual exercise contrary to policy of s.197.
No fresh notification after Pandey reverted from acting Sessions Judge.

respondent_arguments.text: Special Magistrate tries case under normal procedure; no discrimination under Art.14.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Anwar Ali Sarkar's case distinguished

respondent_arguments.text: Trial not commenced; lacunas in sanction can be remedied by evidence at trial.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Gokulchand case; evidence will be given at trial

respondent_arguments.text: S.197(2) permissive; relates to Court, s.14 to Person; no exclusion.
Prepared to issue necessary notification and transfer case regarding Pandey.

court_reasoning.text: Anwar Ali Sarkar applies only where special procedure different from normal prejudices; here Special Magistrate uses normal procedure; no discrimination; law vesting discretion not discriminatory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No discrimination of the kind contemplated by Anwar Ali Sarkar's case arises here.

court_reasoning.text: Trial not commenced; Gokulchand recognizes lacunas remedied by evidence at trial; State will give such evidence; unnecessary to decide validity now.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unnecessary to decide the point whether or not the sanction, as it is, and without such evidence is invalid.

court_reasoning.text: S.197(2) permissive power to specify Court on convenience etc., not protective like s.197(1); no implication from non-exercise; s.197(2) relates to Court, s.14 to Person; specification of Court does not touch who functions in it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The one relates to the Court and the other to the Person.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to pronounce as State prepared to issue notification and transfer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In view of that statement, it is unnecessary to pronounce on the objection so raised.

holdings.text: Section 14 CrPC not violative of Art.14 in this context.
Validity of sanction under s.197(1) not decided as trial pending and can be remedied.
Madras Govt not required to specify court; MP Govt can appoint Special Magistrate under s.14.
Issue of Pandey's appointment not decided.

precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished as no different procedure here; applies only where special procedure prejudices.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Recognizes lacunas in sanction remedied by evidence at trial.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art.32; challenge to s.14 CrPC under Art.14.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Appointment of Special Magistrate; sanction for prosecution of public servant; specification of court.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged: cheating, conspiracy, breach of trust.

outcome.summary: All points raised by petitioners fail; petition under Article 32 dismissed. Observations that questions previously decided against by High Court under Art.226, no appeals taken.

key_quotes.text: That decision, however, applies only to a case where on the allotment of an individual case to a special Court authorised to conduct the trial by a procedure substantially different from the normal procedure, discrimination arises...
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The one relates to the Court and the other to the Person.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key distinction resolving conflict between s.197(2) and s.14 CrPC.

key_quotes.text: In the result, all the points raised on behalf of the petitioners fail, and this petition must be dismissed.
